Organization.address: KTH, AlbaNova University Centre, Stockholm, Stockholm, 106 91, Sweden
Organization.name: Biotechnology

Protocol.text: Slides were scanned at 10 µm resolution immediately after washing using the GMS 418 Array Scanner from Genetic MicroSystems (Affymetrix). The photo multiplier tube setting was set as high as possible, but so as to avoid generation of too many saturated pixels, and to generate approximately balanced signals for Cy3 and Cy5. Images were created using the provided software. Image analysis was carried out using the GenePix Pro 4.1.1.4 software (Axon Instruments, CA, USA). For each slide the foreground and background signal intensities were identified and separated using the adaptive circle segmentation algorithm implemented in the software. A manual inspection was carried out to verify the gridding results.
Protocol.name: Scan GMS 418 and image analysis

Protocol.text:
Text: Three adult mouse neural stem cell cultures were initiated, the first originating from tissue isolated from ten mice (Culture 1) while the second (Culture 2) and third (Culture 3) cultures originated from three mice each. Secondary neurospheres were generated as described in the Neurosphere growth condition protocol.
The secondary neuropheres originating from Culture 1 were harvested for mRNA isolation (Sample A). Approximately a quarter of the secondary neurospheres originating from Culture 2 were also taken for mRNA isolation (Sample B), while the remainder were dissociated and replated in three equal fractions (100,000 cells / well (6 well plate)), cultured in neurosphere medium supplemented with EGF for 3 days, and harvested for mRNA isolation (Samples CI, CII, CIII). Secondary neurospheres originating from Culture 3 were dissociated and divided into two fractions. One fraction was replated (100,000 cells / well (6 well plate)) and cultured identically to the cells generating Samples CI, CII & CIII. After 3 days, the cells were harvested for mRNA isolation (Sample F).
Protocol.name: NS: A, B, CI, CII, CIII and F treatment

Protocol.text:
The lateral wall of the lateral ventricle of 5-6-week-old mice was enzymatically dissociated in 0.8 mg/ml hyaluronidase and 0.5 mg/ml trypsin in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle medium (DMEM) containing 4.5 mg/ml glucose and 80 U/ml DNase at 37°C for 20 min. The cells were gently triturated and mixed with three volumes of neurosphere medium (DMEM/F12, B27 supplement, 12.5 mM HEPES pH7.4) containing 20 ng/ml EGF, 100 U/ml penicillin and 100 g/ml streptomycin. After passing through a 70-m strainer, the cells were pelleted at 160 x g for 5 min. The supernatant was subsequently removed and the cells resuspended in neurosphere medium supplemented as above, plated in uncoated culture dishes and incubated at 37ºC. Neurospheres were ready to be split 7-8 days after plating.
To split neurosphere cultures, neurospheres were collected by centrifugation at 160 x g for 5 min. The neurospheres were resuspended in 0.5 ml Trypsin/EDTA in HBSS (1x), incubated at 37ºC for 2 min and triturated gently to aid dissociation. Following a further three-min incubation at 37ºC and trituration, 3 volumes of ice-cold neurosphere medium containing EGF were added. The cells were pelleted at 220 x g for 4 min, resuspended in fresh neurosphere medium supplemented with 20 ng/ml EGF. Dissociated cells were plated and grown in neurosphere medium supplemented with EGF for a further 3-4 days by which time secondary neurospheres had developed.
Protocol.name: Neurosphere growth condition

Protocol.text:
Extraction and cDNA synthesis:
Messenger RNA was isolated using Dynabeads mRNA DIRECT Kit as instructed by the manufacturer (Dynal A.S., Oslo, Norway).

First and second strand cDNA synthesis was performed using the SuperScript Choice System for cDNA Synthesis according to the manufacturer’s instructions (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA). 45 pmol biotinylated NotI-oligo(dT) primer (5’-biotin-GAGGTGCCAACCGCGGCCGCTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT-3’) was used as first strand synthesis primer. The cDNA was phenol-chloroform extracted, ethanol precipitated and dissolved in 40 µl 1xTE (10 mM Tris-HCl, 1 mM EDTA). Excess NotI-oligo(dT) primer was removed by Chromaspinn TE-100 column (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA, USA).

Amplification was carried out according to the following protocol (see also Hertzberg et al, Plant J 2001, Sievertzon et al, BioTechniques 2004):

1. Sonication
The cDNA is fragmented using an inverted sonication probe (Sonifier® B-12, Branson Sonic Power Company, Danbury, CT, USA)
Pulse 16 times for 10 s at 90% effect. (The cDNA is still in 40 µl 1xTE)

2. Isolation of 3'-ends of cDNA (3'-tags)
Prepare beads:
Use 20 µl Dynal m-280 streptavidin beads per sample (Dynal A.S., Oslo, Norway)
Wash 2x with 40 µl binding/washing buffer (Dynal)
Remove buffer
Add 40 µl binding/washing buffer to the beads
Transfer sonicated sample (in 40 µl 1xTE) to the beads and binding/washing buffer
Bind biotinylated 3’-tags to the streptavidin beads by incubating at 37°C for 1 hour on roller
During incubation begin with step 4.

3. Repair fragments by T4 DNA pol blunt ending
Wash bound product:
remove 80 ml buffer/sample from beads
Wash 2x with 1 x T4 DNA pol buffer (40 µl) (New England BioLabs, Beverly, MA, USA)
remove wash buffer
Add to beads:
3 µl 10 x T4 DNA pol buffer (New England BioLabs)
1.5 µl BSA (1 mg/ml) (New England BioLabs)
0.5 µl T4 DNA polymerase (3 U/ml) (New England BioLabs)
3 µl dNTP mix (1 mM) (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA)
22 µl water

Incubate at 12°C for maximum 20 min, mix a few times to keep beads in solution
Remove repair mix from beads
Wash 2x with 40 µl 1 x 660 ligase buffer (66 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.6, 5 mM MgCl2 5 mM DTT, 50 µg/µl BSA)

4. Ligation of adaptor
Mix in PCR tube:
2 µl Sima19 primer (278 pmol/ml) (5’-TCTCCAGCCTCTCACCGCGGATCC-3’)
2 µl Sima18 primer (278 pmol/ul) (5’-GGATCCGCGGTG-3’)
3 µl 10 x 660 ligase buffer" (660 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.6, 50 mM MgCl2 50 mM DTT, 500 µg/µl BSA)
3 µl ATP (2 mM)
18.5 µl water

Annealing of primers:
1 min at 50°C
gradient: from 50°C to 10°C during 1 hour, leave at 10° if not ready to use directly

Add the above mixture to the washed beads from step 3.
Add 1,5 µl T4 DNA ligase (400 U/ml) (New England BioLabs)
Incubate over night at cool room temperature (preferably down to 16°C, but 20°C works fine), on a roller.

5. Cleave the 3’-tags from the beads (NotI)
Remove the ligation mixture from the beads.
Wash beads with 1 x NEB3 buffer (New England Biolabs)
Remove washbuffer

Add: 6 ml 10 x NEB3 buffer (New England Biolabs)
6 ml BSA (1 mg/ml) (New England Biolabs)
1 ml NotI (10 U/ml) (New England Biolabs)
47 ml water
Incubate at 37°C for 2 hours on "roller"
Transfer supernatant (with 3’-tags) to new tube
Heat inactivate enzyme at 70°C for 20 min

6.Amplification of 3´-tags
PCR amplify 3’-tags using Sima19 and Not1-oligodT,
according to The Plant Journal (2001) 25(5), 585-591
Optimisation of the numbers of cycles needs to be done before
you run your final PCR. Take out 10 ml of sample every 5 cycles
(starting at 15, 20,...35). Run on agarose gel. The optimal number
of cycles is achieved appr 2 cycles before saturation.

Prepare master mix (adjust volumes for multiple samples)
18 µl 5 x PCR buffert (325 mM Tris-HCl pH 8.8, 20 mM MgCl2, 80 mM (NH4)2SO4, 2.5µM BSA)
17 µl dNTPs (2 mM)
7.5 µl Sima19 (10 µM)
7.5 µl biot-NotI-oligo(dT)20 (10 µM)
35 µl water

Prepare hot-start mix (adjust volumes for multiple samples)
2 µl 5 x PCR buffert
0,6 µl AmpliTaq (Perkin Elmer, Boston, MA, USA)
7.4 µl water
Add 5 µl cleaved template into each reaction.

Cycling scheme
5 min at 95°C
add 10 µl hot-start mix
20 min at 72°C
1 min at 95°C ; 5 min at 45°C ; 15 min at 72°C
4 x (1 min at 95°C ; 1 min at 50°C ; 15 min at 72°C)
n x (1 min at 95°C ; 1 min at 50°C ; 2 min at 72°C)
10 min at 72°C
forever at 4°C
n=optimised no of cycles


7. Clean up of PCR product
The amplified 3'-tags were purified using the QIAquick PCR Purification kit (Qiagen GmbH, Hilden, Germany) as instructed by the manufacturer except that the wash step with bfr PE was repeated twice.

Quality control and Quantification:
Due to the limited amount of sample the integrity and concentration of the obtained RNA could not be measured. An agarose gel was run to confirm an obtained PCR product (a smear) with the expected fragment sizes ranging from 50 to 500 bp. The Eppendorf BioPhotometer spectrophotometer (Eppendorf AG, Hamburg, Germany) was used to quantify the amount of PCR product in each sample.
Protocol.name: mRNA ext and 3'-tag amplification

Protocol.text: Each of the samples in the study were generated from pools of lateral ventricle wall tissue from several mice. Specifically, sample A was generated from a pool of ten mice, samples B, CI, CII and CIII were generated from a pool of three mice and samples F and G were generated from another pool of three mice. Pooling was made directly after dissection of the tissue from the brain.
Protocol.name: NS: Pooling of brain tissue

Protocol.text:
Prepare 10x dNTP mix (800µM dATP, dGTP and dTTP, 200µM dCTP):
8µl dATP (100mM)
8µl dGTP (100mM)
8µl dTTP (1oomM)
2µl dCTP (100mM)
974 µl water

Prepare labelling mix:
5µl PCR buffer II (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, Ca, USA)
4µl MgCl2 (25 mM) (Applied Biosystems)
5µl 10x dNTP mix
1µl sima19 primer (50 pmol/µl) (5’-TCTCCAGCCTCTCACCGCGGATCC-3’)
0.6µl ampliTaq gold (5U/µl) (Applied Biosystems)
3µl Cy3-dCTP (1nmol/µl) (Perkin Elmer, Boston, MA, USA)
x µl amplified and purified 3'-tags (100-200 ng)
y µl water
-----
total: 50µl

Cycling:
12 min at 95°C
20 x (30 sec at 95°C; 30 sec at 50°C; 10 min at 72°C)
4°C

The labelled product was purified using the QIAquick PCR Purification kit (Qiagen GmbH, Hilden, Germany) as instructed by the manufacturer except that the wash step with buffer PE was repeated twice. It was vacuum dried until dry and kept in dark in -20°C until hybridisation.
Protocol.name: Direct labelling of ampl 3'-tags, Cy3

Protocol.text:
Prepare 10x dNTP mix (800µM dATP, dGTP and dTTP, 200µM dCTP):
8µl dATP (100mM)
8µl dGTP (100mM)
8µl dTTP (1oomM)
2µl dCTP (100mM)
974 µl water

Prepare labelling mix:
5µl PCR buffer II (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, Ca, USA)
4µl MgCl2 (25 mM) (Applied Biosystems)
5µl 10x dNTP mix
1µl sima19 primer (50 pmol/µl) (5’-TCTCCAGCCTCTCACCGCGGATCC-3’)
0.6µl ampliTaq gold (5U/µl) (Applied Biosystems)
3µl Cy5-dCTP (1nmol/µl) (Perkin Elmer, Boston, MA, USA)
x µl amplified and purified 3'-tags (100-200 ng)
y µl water
-----
total: 50µl

Cycling:
12 min at 95°C
20 x (30 sec at 95°C; 30 sec at 50°C; 10 min at 72°C)
4°C

The labelled product was purified using the QIAquick PCR Purification kit (Qiagen GmbH, Hilden, Germany) as instructed by the manufacturer except that the wash step with buffer PE was repeated twice. It was vacuum dried until dry and kept in dark in -20°C until hybridisation.
Protocol.name: Direct labelling of ampl 3'-tags, Cy5

Protocol.text:
Slide preparation:
Slides were pre-hybridised at 42°C for 45 min in a water bath. The pre-hybridisation mix consisted of 5 x SSC, 1% BSA (Sigma-Aldrich) and 0.1% SDS. The slides were washed in water and isopropanol, dried through centrifugation in a slide centrifuge (Telechem) and used within an hour.

Target preparation:
The total amount of Cy3- and Cy5-labelled targets, generated from asymmetric PCR of 100-200 ng 3'-tags per sample, was used for hybridisation. Purified and vacuum dried targets were pooled in 120 µl of hybridisation mixture. Hybridisation mixture had a final composition of 5x SSC, 25% formamide, 0.1% SDS, 50 µg poly(dA) and 25 µg mouse COT-1 DNA. The mixture was denaturated at 95 °C for 3 minutes and stored on ice until injected under the coverslip.

Hybridisation:
Hybridisation in a total volume of 120µl was carried out for 16-18 hours at 42°C in Corning hyb chambers placed in water bath.

Wash:
Hybridised slides were washed for four minutes with 1x SSC and 0.2% SDS at 42°C, followed by 0.1x SSC and 0.2% SDS at room temperature (four minutes) and finally by a four minute wash with 0.1x SSC at room temperature. Washed slides were immediately dried using a slide centrifuge (Telechem).
Protocol.name: Hybridisation protocol

Protocol.text:
Normalisation was conducted in R using the aroma (http://www.maths.lth.se/publications/) and kth (http://www.biotech.kth.se/molbio/microarray/) packages.

1. The median of the local background was subtracted from the median of the foreground signal.
2. Unreliable data was removed from the data set using functions in the kth-pacakge. A feature was considered unreliable if it was flagged as Not Found by GenePix or manually flagged as bad during the image analysis step. Furthermore, if a feature satisfied one of the following criteria it was considered unreliable: a) both channels were saturated (above 65100 intensity units), b) the size of the feature was abnormal (below 110 and above 230 ìm in diameter), c) the percentage of foreground pixels above the local background plus two of its standard deviations were below 70 for both channels
3. The remaining data was normalised using functions in the aroma-package. Normalisation was made separately for each individual block on the slide using a robust local regression; print-tip lowess normalisation. The fraction of data (span) used in each local regression was set to 0.3.
Protocol.name: NS: data normalisation

Protocol.text:
Three adult mouse neural stem cell cultures were initiated, the first originating from tissue isolated from ten mice (Culture 1) while the second (Culture 2) and third (Culture 3) cultures originated from three mice each. Secondary neurospheres were generated as described in the Neurosphere growth condition protocol.
Secondary neurospheres from Culture 3 were dissociated and divided into two fractions. One fraction was replated in neurosphere medium supplemented with 1% fetal calf serum (FCS) onto poly-D-lysine plates to which the cells adhered. After incubating, overnight FCS concentration was reduced to 0.5%, and the cells cultured a further 2 days before centrifugation and subsequent mRNA isolation.
Protocol.name: NS: sample G treatment (differentiation)

Protocol.text:
All transformation steps were conducted in R using the Bioconductor package bundle (http://www.bioconductor.org/) and the LIMMA (http://www.bepress.com/sagmb/vol3/iss1/art3/), aroma (http://www.maths.lth.se/publications/) and kth (http://www.biotech.kth.se/molbio/microarray/) packages.

1. GenePix result files were imported into R and gene expression measurements were obtained for each feature by subtracting the median of the local background from the median of the foreground signal.
2. Cy3 and Cy5 signals were converted to M (=log2(intensity Cy5/intensity Cy3)) and A (=log2(intensity Cy5 * intensity Cy3)) format.
3. A filter was used to identify and correct for features that had one channel (Cy3 or Cy5) below the background or at zero and one channel stronger than the background. The signal in the weaker channel was for these spots set to one plus the intensity of the local background. Features with both channels below the background or at zero were removed from the data set.
4. Unreliable data was removed from normalisation and further analysis. A feature was considered unreliable if it was flagged as Not Found by GenePix or manually flagged as bad during the image analysis step. Furthermore, if a feature satisfied one of the following criteria it was considered unreliable: a) both channels were saturated (above 65100 intensity units), b) the size of the feature was abnormal (below 110 and above 230 ìm in diameter), c) the percentage of foreground pixels above the local background plus two of its standard deviations were below 70 for both channels
5. The remaining data was normalised separately for each individual block on the slide using a robust local regression, print-tip lowess normalisation.
6. Differentially expressed genes were identified using an empirical Bayes moderated t-test. The experimental design included reciprocal dye label assignments. These were swapped prior to the moderated t-test so that in each comparison the genes in the sample with an abbreviation that comes earlier in alphabetical order (e.g. B in B vs. CI) have positive M-values if they have a higher expression level. The duplicate features on each array are expected to have a higher correlation than the replicated hybridisations. This information was considered in the linear model by first estimating the duplicate feature correlation using the dupcor.series function of the Limma package. Secondly, a linear model was fit for each probe using generalised least squares, which takes into account the duplicate feature correlation. In the third step an empirical Bayes approach was used to shrink the gene-wise standard errors towards a common value and a moderated t-statistic was calculated. The p-values associated with this t-statistics were adjusted using false-discovery rate control. Finally, probabilities for differential expression (also known as B-values or log-odds) were calculated for each gene. For the calculation of the B-values the a priori assumption of differentially expressed genes was set to 0.01.
7. A gene was considered differentially expressed if the adjusted p-value was < 0.001.
Protocol.name: NS: data transformation

Description.text: Primary cell culture from brain biopsy
Primary cell culture from brain biopsy
Primary cell culture from brain biopsy

Experiment.name: Primary neural stem cell transcriptome variability

Description.text: Investigation of transcriptome variability in neurospheres originating from separate isolations (individuals), different passages and parallel cultures. As a control neurospheres were also compared to neurospheres induced to differentiate by adding serum and plating onto solid support.

BibliographicReference.title: Transcriptome analysis in primary neural stem cells using a tag cDNA amplification method
BibliographicReference.authors: Maria Sievertzon; Valtteri Wirta; Alex Mercer; Konstantinos Meletis; Rikard Erlandsson; Lilian Wikström; Jonas Frisén; Joakim Lundeberg

OntologyEntry.description: neurosphere medium supplemented with 1% fetal calf serum (FCS)
number of cell passages after isolation from brain
pool of mice from which sample was taken

Description.text: Since measurement of the sample-to-sample variation was the main goal of the study it was not possible to include biological replicates. We did however use four technical replicates for each sample, includng dye swaps, as well as duplicate spots on arrays.
